title: DP World's covert action claim rejected
text:
While DP Mansini of FWC “acknowledged that DP World’s hypothesis is not without merit” and she did not “necessarily accept the broad denials” of two of the Melbourne terminal union organisers, she nonetheless rejected DP World’s position that a covert campaign had been organised.

DP Mansini reported that “difficult questions arise from the productivity data” that DP World had presented before taking issue with the “foundation” of the comparisons of productivity that underpinned DP World’s case before both the federal court and FWC.

Productivity figures

“DP World’s case hinges on the premise that the measure of a go-slow is to be found in productivity figures achieved in the period 14 July 2019 to 7 August 2019 as against the average figures for the period April to June 2019,” DP Mansini assessed.

“I accept that averaged data may, in a case of this nature, be useful to establish a significant reduction in productivity. However, in this case, it is not contentious that there were other coinciding events during DP World’s selected comparative period. Those events included protected industrial action taken during April, March and June 2019 and changed work practices over the same period,” she concluded.

DP Mansini accepted evidence that crane and straddle productivity had steadily risen over April to June because of the new management’s attempts to improve customer service and turnaround times. As a result, “these figures do not represent a common of normal business scenario”.

“Even having regard to [the] justifications for selecting this period ... in all of the circumstances and given the significance and seriousness of what is alleged, the discrete period of April to June 2019 does not appear to be an ideal comparator or sound foundation on which to proceed,” she decided.

Quite obviously, this was not the view taken in the Federal Court where effectively the same data points of productivity decline were presented to the court by the same DP World managers.

Advertisement

In the Federal Court DP World successfully supported its claim of a “sudden and significant drop in productivity” at the West Swanson terminal with a set of data rich in detail and drama.

Hallmarks of co-ordination

It was claimed, for example, that after July’s protected action, the land-side straddles that carry containers around the terminal were taking 7 per cent more time to travel 4 per cent less distance and that 83 per cent of straddle drivers had generated worse than average performance through that 16-day period.

DP World claimed that reported equipment faults from straddle drivers had risen 250 per cent through the back end of July against what they had been in the week before the stoppage, and that some complaints had been “as obviously trivial as the presence of rubbish in a straddle cabin”.

It reported that crane availability through the second half of July had suddenly fallen to a 2019 low and crane movements were 28 per cent lower than they had been through April and June.

It argued that “by its nature, the gross moves per hour metric accounts for the various forms of protected industrial action that the CFMMEU and its members have waged throughout July 2019” and claimed that none of the performance retreats described could be attributable to operational or environmental factors such as breakdowns or inclement weather.

And, in issuing his August decision against the union, Justice Snaden identified that this downshift in performance appeared to hold “all the hallmarks of sophisticated, central co-ordination; and to have been executed by a person or persons who apparently command the loyalty of a significant proportion of the relevant employees”. In other words, the union or its officials had arranged covert action and it had to stop.

Advertisement

DP World and the union have been at loggerheads with the waterfront union since March over a proposed new enterprise agreement that attempts to embed new roster flexibilities in the name of cost management and productivity.

The roots of DP World’s need for reform lie in the changed competitive framework of the stevedoring industry and the aligned facts that the port operator’s share of the Australian container market and its financial performance have withered dramatically over the past year or so.

In April, just a month into the union negotiations, new DP World chief executive Glen Hilton warned that competition from Melbourne’s fully automated third player was a sectoral game-changer whose impact was not yet fully appreciated by the union.

Flexibility or automation

In what was his first interview since taking over from high profile predecessor Paul Scurrah, Hilton told The Australian Financial Review: “The big change on the waterfront is the level of automation and I don’t think the union, in terms of its approach, have adapted to that.”

Then, foreshadowing the contest now in play, Hilton warned: “Volumes are down because of new entrants. They have cheaper operating models because they don’t have the level of labour on site. But it is hard to get them [the union] to put that into the conversation or get them into that reality.

“If there is any major port operator that needs to have flexibility [in its EA] it is DP. Flexibility is our issue,” he said. “We have lost significant volumes in Melbourne and we have to deal with the outcome of that.”

To be clear on that, DP is a manual operator in Melbourne and Sydney and is only semi-automated in Brisbane. But in each of those three key east coast destinations, it faces increasingly automated competition – Patrick in Brisbane and Sydney and Victoria International Container Terminal in Melbourne.

In August, Hilton said DP World owned neither the need nor the desire to speed down the new technology path. Instead, Hilton was banking on the potential of workplace reform that would allow DP World to more successfully harvest the capital it had already deployed.

“It is an economic decision eventually,” he said. “We don’t see ourselves having to go down that path in the short-to-medium term. It depends on arrangements we can build with our stakeholders in the unions,” he told the Financial Review in August. “If things become unmanageable, we have that option.”

Whether the current state of negotiations and contest has reached that tipping point, time should very quickly tell.
description: The Fair Work Commission has rejected docker's data supporting claims of a waterfront "go slow".
